Stock Application¶

Documentation for the ‘stock’ app.

Forms¶

class stock.forms.ProductForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: ModelForm

A form for managing ‘Product’ objects.

This form includes fields for product details such as name, supplier, description, price, and stock. Custom widgets are used to enhance the user interface.

Parameters:

Meta – Specifies the model and fields to be used in the form, along with custom widgets.

class Meta[source]¶

Bases: object

Metaclass for ProductForm.

Defines the model, fields to include, and widgets for form rendering.

Bases: ModelForm

A form for managing ‘StockMovement’ objects.

This form includes fields for stock movement details such as quantity, movement type, and reason. Custom widgets are used to enhance the user interface.

clean_quantity()[source]¶

Clean and validate the quantity field.

This method checks if a quantity value has been provided and raises a ValidationError if it’s missing.

Returns:

The cleaned quantity value.

Return type:

int or float

Raises:

ValidationError – If the quantity is None or not provided.

Models¶

class stock.models.Product(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: Model

Represents a product in the inventory.

This model stores information about products, including name, description, supplier, price, stock, and last update time.

exception DoesNotExist¶

This method ensures the price is not a negative value.

Raises:

reduce_stock(quantity)[source]¶

Reduces the stock of the product by the specified quantity.

Parameters:

quantity (int) – The quantity to reduce from the stock.

Raises:

ValueError – If there is insufficient stock.

stock¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

stock_movement¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

supplier¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

supplier_id¶
update_at¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

class stock.models.StockMovement(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: Model

Represents a movement in the stock of a product.

This model stores information about stock movements, including the product, quantity, type of movement, reason, and creation time.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
products¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

Views¶

stock.views.add_products(request)[source]¶

Add a new product.

This view handles both GET and POST requests for adding a new product. It renders a form for product creation and processes the form submission.

Parameters:

request – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the product creation form or redirect to supplier list.

stock.views.add_supplier(request)[source]¶

Add a new supplier.

This view handles POST requests for adding a new supplier. It creates a new Supplier object with the provided name.

Parameters:

request – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Redirect to the supplier list page.

stock.views.create_stock_movement(request, product_id)[source]¶

Create a new stock movement for a specific product.

This view handles both GET and POST requests for creating a new stock movement. It renders a form for stock movement creation and processes the form submission. After successful creation, it updates the product’s stock accordingly.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • product_id – The ID of the product for which the stock movement is being created.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the stock movement creation form or redirect to product details.

Raises:

Http404 – If the product with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.delete_product(request, product_id)[source]¶

Delete a specific product.

This view handles the deletion of a product. It requires a POST request to actually delete the product.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • product_id – The ID of the product to be deleted.

Returns:

Redirect to the supplier list page after successful deletion, or confirmation page for GET requests.

Raises:

Http404 – If the product with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.delete_supplier(request, supplier_id)[source]¶

Delete a specific supplier.

This view handles POST requests for deleting a supplier. It deletes the supplier with the given ID.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • supplier_id – The ID of the supplier to be deleted.

Returns:

Redirect to the supplier list page.

Raises:

Http404 – If the supplier with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.details_product(request, product_id)[source]¶

Display details of a specific product.

This view retrieves and displays the details of a single product.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • product_id – The ID of the product to be viewed.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the product details.

Raises:

Http404 – If the product with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.edit_product(request, product_id)[source]¶

Edit an existing product.

This view handles both GET and POST requests for editing a product. It retrieves the product details, renders a form for editing, and processes the form submission.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • product_id – The ID of the product to be edited.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the product edit form or redirect to product details.

Raises:

Http404 – If the product with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.edit_supplier(request, supplier_id)[source]¶

Edit an existing supplier.

This view handles POST requests for editing a supplier. It updates the name of the supplier with the given ID.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • supplier_id – The ID of the supplier to be edited.

Returns:

Redirect to the products page for the supplier.

Raises:

Http404 – If the supplier with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.list_supplier(request)[source]¶

Display a list of all suppliers and products without a supplier.

This view retrieves all suppliers and products that do not belong to any supplier.

Parameters:

request – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the list of suppliers and products without a supplier.

stock.views.products_supplier(request, supplier_id)[source]¶

Display products for a specific supplier.

This view retrieves all products for a given supplier and paginates the results.

Parameters:

  • request – The HTTP request object.

  • supplier_id – The ID of the supplier whose products are being viewed.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the list of products for the supplier.

Raises:

Http404 – If the supplier with the given ID does not exist.

stock.views.products_without_supplier(request)[source]¶

Display products that do not belong to any supplier.

This view retrieves all products that have no associated supplier.

Parameters:

request – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the list of products without a supplier.

stock.views.search_product(request)[source]¶

Search for products based on a query.

This view handles searching for products based on the provided query.

Parameters:

request – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Rendered HTML page with the search results.

URLs¶

URL Configuration for the Stock Management app.

This module defines the URL patterns for the Stock Management application. It maps URLs to view functions, allowing users to interact with suppliers, products, and stock movements.

URL Patterns:

Supplier Views: - ‘supplier/list/’: Maps to the list_supplier view for listing all suppliers. - ‘supplier/add/’: Maps to the add_supplier view for creating a new supplier. - ‘supplier/edit/<int:supplier_id>/’: Maps to the edit_supplier view for editing an existing supplier. - ‘supplier/delete/<int:supplier_id>/’: Maps to the delete_supplier view for deleting a supplier.

Product Views: - ‘product/add/’: Maps to the add_products view for creating a new product. - ‘product/details/<int:product_id>/’: Maps to the details_product view for viewing product details. - ‘product/delete/<int:product_id>/’: Maps to the delete_product view for deleting a product. - ‘product/edit/<int:product_id>/’: Maps to the edit_product view for editing an existing product. - ‘product/products_supplier/<int:supplier_id>/’: Maps to the products_supplier view for listing products of a specific supplier. - ‘product/products/no-supplier/’: Maps to the products_without_supplier view for listing products without a supplier. - ‘product/search/’: Maps to the search_product view for searching products.

Stock Views: - ‘stock/create_movement/<int:product_id>/’: Maps to the create_stock_movement view for creating a stock movement for a specific product.

Note

The ‘app_name’ variable is set to ‘stock’, which is used for namespacing these URLs.

Usage:

To include these URLs in the main project URLs, use: path(‘stock/’, include(‘stock.urls’))
